title: Reform Group (Ireland)
text:
The Reform Group was an organisation based in <a href="Dublin">Dublin</a> that sought to have <a href="Republic%20of%20Ireland">Ireland</a> rejoin the <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a>.
History.
The group was launched in 1998 as The Reform Movement shortly after the successful referendum ratifying the <a href="Good%20Friday%20Agreement">Good Friday Agreement</a> and describing itself as a coalition of "new unionists for the new millennium".
A number of its founders, such as Anne Holliday, had been members of the anti-<a href="Irish%20republicanism">republican</a> group, New Consensus. At its launch, the group called for:
The group claims to be a voice for "alternative viewpoints" of "Irishmen and Irishwomen who do not fit in the seamless definition" of <a href="Irish%20nationalism">nationalist</a> or <a href="Unionism%20in%20Ireland">unionist</a>. It has previously voiced support for <a href="Irish%20nationality%20law">citizens of Ireland</a> being given the right to apply for British passports. The group has also expressed views that are critical of the status of the <a href="Irish%20language">Irish language</a>.
In May 2010, the group launched a book called, "Ireland and the Commonwealth: Towards Membership". Speaking at the launch were independent Senator <a href="David%20Norris%20%28politician%29">David Norris</a>, writer <a href="Mary%20Kenny">Mary Kenny</a> and <a href="Trinity%20College%2C%20Dublin">Trinity College</a> professor Robert Martin, all of whom stated their support for Ireland rejoining the Commonwealth. It was described in "<a href="The%20Phoenix%20%28magazine%29">The Phoenix</a>" magazine as a "ridiculous Unionist ginger group".
Logo.
At its inception and for some years afterwards, the "badge" or logo of The Reform Group was <a href="Saint%20Patrick%27s%20Cross">Saint Patrick's Cross</a>, a white flag with a red saltire. This was a controversial choice of symbol as the authenticity of the symbol as one representing Ireland has often been debated.
